Docs.summary: A that occupies an area on the screen, has a visual appearance, and can obtain touch input.

remarks.para: The base class for most Microsoft.Maui.Controls on-screen elements. Provides most properties, events, and methods for presenting an item on screen.

Docs.summary: Signals the end of a batch of commands to the element and that those commands should now be committed.
Docs.remarks: This method merely ensures that updates sent during the batch have been committed. It does not ensure that they were not committed before calling this.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the desired height override of this element.
Docs.value: The height this element desires to be.
Docs.remarks: HeightRequest does not immediately change the Bounds of a VisualElement, however setting the HeightRequest will change the result of calls to GetSizeRequest, which will in turn modify the final size the element receives during a layout cycle.
To revert to the default "auto" behavior of this property, use ClearValue(HeightRequestProperty).

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool InputTransparent { bool get(); void set(bool value); };
member this.InputTransparent : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this element should be involved in the user interaction cycle. This is a bindable property.
Docs.value: if the element and its children should receive input; if neither the element nor its children should receive input and should, instead, pass inputs to the elements that are visually behind the current visual element. Default is .
Docs.remarks: Setting InputTransparent is not the same as setting IsEnabled to false. Setting InputTransparent only disables inputs and instead causes them to be passed to the that is visually behind the element. Usually, this is the parent of the element. The value of the property is inherited by a visual element's child elements.

Public Shared ReadOnly InputTransparentProperty As BindableProperty

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this element is enabled in the user interface. This is a bindable property.
Docs.value: if the element is enabled; otherwise, . The default value is

remarks.para: Elements that are not enabled do not participate in hit detection, and therefore will not receive focus or emit input events.
The following example shows a handler on a button which will then set IsEnabled to false on another button.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines whether this elements should be part of the visual tree or not. This is a bindable property.
Docs.value: if the element should be rendered; otherwise, . Default value is .

remarks.para: Setting IsVisible to false will remove the element from the visual tree. The element will no longer take up space in layouts or be eligle to receive any kind of input event.
The following example shows a stack where the middle element is toggled when a button is activated.

public: property double MinimumHeightRequest { double get(); void set(double value); };
member this.MinimumHeightRequest : double with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value which overrides the minimum height the element will request during layout.
Docs.value: The minimum height the element requires. Default value is -1.

remarks.para: MinimumHeightRequest is used to override the results of a call to GetSizeRequest by setting the minimum height property. This causes overflow handling to shrink this element to its minimum height before elements who do not have a minimum size set.
The following example sets the MinimumHeightRequest to enable an image to shrink below its normal size.

public: property double Opacity { double get(); void set(double value); };
member this.Opacity : double with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the opacity value applied to the element when it is rendered. This is a bindable property.
Docs.value: The opacity value. Default opacity is 1.0. Values will be clamped between 0 and 1 on set.

remarks.para: The opacity value has no effect unless IsVisible is . Opacity is inherited down the element hierarchy. If a parent has 0.5 opacity, and a child has 0.5 opacity, the child will render with an effective 0.25 opacity. Setting opacity to 0 has undefined behavior with input elements.
The following example sets the opacity of a layout to 0.5 and the opacity of one of its children to 0.5, making the child 25% opaque.

Public Shared ReadOnly OpacityProperty As BindableProperty

public: property Microsoft::Maui::Controls::ResourceDictionary ^ Resources { Microsoft::Maui::Controls::ResourceDictionary ^ get(); void set(Microsoft::Maui::Controls::ResourceDictionary ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the local resource dictionary.
Docs.value: The current resource dictionary, where resources are stored by key.

remarks.para: In XAML, resource dictionaries are filled with key/value pairs that are specified in XML and consequently created at run time. The keys in the resource dictionary are specified with the x:Key attribute of the XML tag for the type to create. An object of that type is created, and is initialized with the property and field values that are specified either by additional attributes or by nested tags, both of which, when present are simply string representations of the property or field names. The object is then inserted into the for the enclosing type at runtime.

example.para: For example, the XAML below, taken from the XAML for Microsoft.Maui.Controls series, creates a resource dictionary that contains object constants that can be used for any objects that are added to the surrounding :

Note that the above snippet is only valid when nested within a <ContentPage>...</ContentPage> tag pair. Within that pair, the app developer can use both of the horzOptions and vertOptions keys to specify values for properties of type by using the "{...}" static resource syntax. The short example below, also taken from the XAML for Microsoft.Maui.Controls series, illustrates this syntax:
example.code: <Button Text="Do this!" HorizontalOptions="{StaticResource horzOptions}" VerticalOptions="{StaticResource vertOptions}" BorderWidth="3" Rotation="-15" TextColor="Red" Font="Large" />
example.para: Resource dictionaries and their associated XML provide the application developer with a convenient method to reuse code inside the XAML compile-time and run-time engines.

member this.TranslationX : double with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the X translation delta of the element.
Docs.value: The amount to translate the element.
Docs.remarks: Translation is applied post layout. It is particularly good for applying animations. Translating an element outside the bounds of its parent container may prevent inputs from working.

Docs.summary: Gets the current rendered width of this element. This is a read-only bindable property.
Docs.value: The renderered width of this element.
Docs.remarks: The width of an element is set during the Layout phase.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class Microsoft.Maui.Controls.BindableProperty WidthProperty
Public Shared ReadOnly WidthProperty As BindableProperty
public: property double WidthRequest { double get(); void set(double value); };
member this.WidthRequest : double with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the desired width override of this element.
Docs.value: The width this element desires to be.
Docs.remarks: WidthRequest does not immediately change the Bounds of a VisualElement, however setting the WidthRequest will change the result of calls to GetSizeRequest, which will in turn modify the final size the element receives during a layout cycle.
To revert to the default "auto" behavior of this property, use ClearValue(WidthRequestProperty).
